title-group.article-title: Immobilized Ni and Cu on eucalyptus/MGO as a green heterogeneous catalyst for tetrazoles synthesis through RSM optimization

contrib-group.aff: 1https://ror.org/01rws6r75grid.411230.50000 0000 9296 6873Nanotechnology Research Centre, Ahvaz Jundishapur University of Medical Sciences, Ahvaz, Iran
2https://ror.org/04xgbph11grid.412537.60000 0004 1768 2925Department of Chemistry, Gobardanga Hindu College, 24-Parganas (North), Gobardanga, India

abstract.p: In this research, magnetic graphene oxide (MGO) was first synthesized through straightforward methods and subsequently functionalized with Eucalyptus leaf extract. Following this, nickel and copper metal salts were stabilized onto the prepared nanocomposite support. The successful synthesis and properties of the resulting catalysts were confirmed using a suite of physicochemical characterization techniques. These novel nanostructures demonstrated high catalytic activity in the synthesis of tetrazole derivatives. To achieve optimal reaction conditions, a Box-Behnken experimental design was utilized in conjunction with Response Surface Methodology (RSM) to investigate the influence of key parameters, including reaction time, catalyst amount, and temperature. A significant advantage of these catalysts is their magnetic nature, which allows for simple and efficient recovery from the reaction mixture using an external magnet. The catalysts were successfully reused for five consecutive cycles without a discernible decrease in their reactivity, highlighting their stability and potential for cost-effective applications.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Heterocyclic compounds are a crucial and widespread class of organic molecules essential to chemistry. They feature a ring structure containing at least one atom other than carbon, such as nitrogen, oxygen, or sulfur. This incorporation of heteroatoms imparts distinct chemical and physical properties compared to their all-carbon counterparts, influencing the molecule’s electronic distribution and reactivity1,2. The versatility of these compounds makes them fundamental building blocks in numerous applications. They are vital in the development of pharmaceuticals, with a significant percentage of drugs containing a heterocyclic ring. Additionally, they are used in agrochemicals, such as herbicides and pesticides, as well as in advanced materials like plastics, polymers, and dyes3,4.

Among the vast array of heterocycles, tetrazoles have garnered significant attention for a variety of applications5. They are particularly noted as environmentally friendly, high-energy materials suitable for pyrotechnics, explosives, gas generators, and propellants6–9. The high nitrogen content and endothermic heat of formation of tetrazoles contribute to their energetic properties10,11.

In medicinal chemistry, the tetrazole ring is highly significant as a bioisostere for carboxylic acids. This substitution is advantageous due to the enhanced metabolic stability of tetrazoles, which are resistant to biological degradation pathways that typically affect carboxylic acids.This resistance can prolong a drug’s activity in the body12–16. The incorporation of a tetrazole can also improve the molecular stability and therapeutic efficacy of various drugs, including antibiotics and anticancer agents. Their application is also prominent in anti-inflammatory and antiviral medications due to their high biological activity and low toxicity. Consequently, tetrazoles are considered a valuable structural platform for designing novel pharmaceuticals17–23. Notably, losartan (1a) and valsartan (1b) are widely prescribed for the management of hypertension. Additionally, the tetrazole derivative pemirolast (1c) is utilized as an anti-allergic medication. (Fig. 1).

caption.p: Chemical structure of losartan (a), valsartan (b) and pemirolast (c).

sec.p: The synthesis of tetrazoles has been a significant focus of chemical research in recent decades, with catalysts playing a pivotal role in these processes. The use of catalysts is instrumental in steering chemical reactions toward greener and more environmentally sustainable pathways. Catalytic methods, particularly those employing nanomaterials, offer several advantages in tetrazole synthesis, including high efficiency, shorter reaction times, and the potential for catalyst recovery and reusability. These advancements align with the principles of green chemistry by minimizing waste and employing more benign reaction conditions23–27. Driven by both environmental and economic concerns, magnetic nanocatalysts have gained significant importance due to their facile separation and recyclability, which is critical given the high cost of many catalytic materials28–33. They provide a high surface area and straightforward separation via an external magnet. Consequently, ensuring the stability of these magnetic nanoparticles in both aqueous and organic media is crucial for controlling their catalytic properties and the quality of the final products34–39.

Pure metals such as copper, iron, and cobalt, along with their alloys, are notably susceptible to oxidation when exposed to air. To enhance the stability of nanoparticles derived from these metals and to create suitable substrates for various catalysts, a range of surface modification techniques have been developed. These methods often involve coating the nanoparticles with small molecules or enveloping them in layers of organic and inorganic polymers. Significantly, when these nanoparticles possess strong magnetic properties and a surface covered with hydroxyl groups, they become excellent candidates for further surface modification. This is because the hydroxyl groups provide reactive sites for the attachment of other functional molecules, allowing for the fine-tuning of the catalyst’s properties for specific applications40–47.

Graphene oxide (GO) is a two-dimensional nanostructure of a single-layer carbon lattice functionalized with oxygen-containing groups48–51. While these groups reduce the electrical and thermal conductivity found in pristine graphene, they significantly boost its chemical reactivity, hydrophilicity, and dispersibility. This enhanced reactivity makes GO an ideal platform for creating composite materials48–51. Its biocompatibility and high surface area enable wide-ranging applications in medicine, including drug delivery, tissue engineering, biosensors, and biocatalysis[52–57]. Additionally, GO can be reduced to a graphene-like material, which partially restores its conductivity for potential use in electronics52–57.

This work presents a sustainable synthesis of a magnetic graphene oxide nanocomposite. The process begins with the economical, in-situ production of nano CuFe2O4 encapsulated on graphene oxide. This nanocomposite is then biogenically modified with eucalyptus leaf extract, which facilitates the green synthesis of secondary copper (Cu) and nickel (Ni) nanoparticles onto the matrix. Copper and nickel-based nanocatalysts are known for their high efficiency in various chemical reactions. Their large active surface area and enhanced electron transfer capabilities allow reactions to occur under milder conditions with greater efficiency. These catalysts also exhibit favorable thermal stability and resistance to poisoning. Recent studies highlight their potential in developing sustainable and environmentally friendly chemical processes. Notably, biogenic nanoparticles synthesized using natural sources like plants are gaining prominence in medicine and pharmaceuticals due to their eco-friendly production. These nanoparticles offer significant advantages, including lower toxicity, higher biocompatibility, and reduced production costs, making them ideal candidates for therapeutic applications58–61.

The catalytic performance of a newly synthesized hybrid nanocomposite was assessed for creating various tetrazole derivatives. Response Surface Methodology (RSM) was employed to efficiently determine the optimal reaction conditions by systematically adjusting parameters like catalyst amount, temperature, and time. The key advantages of this method include high efficiency in short reaction times, the use of common and non-toxic starting materials, and a straightforward procedure. The catalyst design itself is notable for being inexpensive and environmentally friendly, thanks to the use of eucalyptus extract.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: The chemicals and solvents used in this project were obtained from Sigma Aldrich and Merck. Eucalyptus leaves were collected from trees in Ahvaz Province, Iran. Morphological study was done using SEM analysis on FESEM-TESCAN MIRA3 device. FT-IR was performed on a KBr disk in a BRUKER (VRTEX 70) FT-IR spectrophotometer. XRD study was performed using Cu Ka radiation (λ = 1.54060 Å). MDKFD VSM tool was used to study magnetism.

sec.title: Synthesis of MGO nanoparticles
sec.p: Hummer process was used in the synthesis of GO. First, a mixture of 2.0 g of powdered graphite, 1.0 g of NaNO3, 6.0 g of KMnO4, and 60 mL of H2SO4 (98%) was stirred for 2 h at 0 °C, and subsequently the greenish-black paste was brought to 35 °C and kept for another 2 h. The solution was then diluted with 150 mL of distilled water when the reaction mixture was superheated to 98 °C. 10 mL of 30% H2O2 was added after cooling to 60 °C and stirred for an additional 2 h. The solid residue was filtered and washed with dilute HCl and then distilled water to neutral pH. The obtained graphite oxide was then dried in vacuum at 60 °C. Finally, it was exfoliated to GO by sonicating in water for 2 h. A green biometric approach was followed in the synthesis. In the usual method, 1.0 g of GO was dispersed in a solution of deionized water containing salts CuCl2·2H2O (11.43 mmol) and FeCl3·6H2O (22.8 mmol) as CuFe2O4 precursor. The whole mixture was made strongly alkaline (pH = 11) by adding NaOH solution (0.1 M) and stirred for 2 hours. The resulting white precipitate was magnetically separated, washed with deionized water and EtOH, and finally dried under vacuum at 70°C for 12 hours to afford the Magnetic Graphene Oxide (MGO).

sec.title: Synthesis of Ni/ELE@MGO and Cu/ELE@MGO nanoparticles
sec.p: To synthesize the catalysts, eucalyptus leaf extract (ELE) was first prepared by soaking 50 g of leaves in 120 ml of a water/ethanol mixture for two weeks. Separately, 0.5 g of magnetic graphene oxide (MGO) was dispersed in ethanol. The ELE was then added to the MGO dispersion and stirred for 24 h to produce a composite (ELE@MGO), which was magnetically separated and dried. In the final step, 1.0 g of ELE@MGO was mixed with either a copper or nickel salt in ethanol and refluxed for 16 h. The resulting Cu/ELE@MGO and Ni/ELE@MGO catalysts were collected using a magnet, washed, and dried. The phytochemicals in the eucalyptus extract acted as reducing and stabilizing agents, preventing nanoparticle aggregation and ensuring uniform size. (Fig. 2).

caption.p: Schematic preparation of m/ELE@MGO (m = Ni or Cu) nanocatalyst.

sec.title: General procedure for the synthesis of 5-substituted tetrazoles
sec.p: A certain amount of catalyst (m/ELE@MGO, M = Ni or Cu) was added to a mixture containing PEG (2 ml), benzonitrile (1 mmol) and sodium azide (1.2mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred vigorously at 120 °C for a suitable time. After completion of the reaction (monitored by TLC), the catalyst was separated by a magnet, and then HCl (4 N, 10 mL) was added to the remaining mixture, and the corresponding tetrazole was extracted with ethyl acetate. The resulting organic layer was washed with distilled water to produce the corresponding tetrazoles (Fig. 3).

caption.p: m/ELE@MGO(m = Ni or Cu)catalyzed the one-pot synthesis of 5-substituted tetrazoles.

sec.title: Catalyst characterizations
sec.p: Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was employed to investigate the surface functional groups of the synthesised materials, with spectra recorded in the 400–3500 cm⁻¹ range (Fig. 4). The FT-IR spectrum for MGO, presented in Fig. 4a, displays several characteristic absorption bands. A broad absorption region observed between 3100 and 3500 cm⁻¹ is attributed to the O-H stretching vibrations of hydroxyl groups and intercalated water molecules. Other prominent peaks are located at 1730 cm⁻¹, corresponding to the C = O stretching of carboxyl groups, 1410 cm⁻¹ for C-OH stretching, and 1084 cm⁻¹, which is assigned to C-O stretching vibrations. The spectrum also reveals distinct peaks at lower wavenumbers, specifically at 612 cm⁻¹ and 436 cm⁻¹, which are characteristic of Fe-O and Cu-O stretching vibrations in the CuFe₂O₄ spinel structure, respectively. The concurrent presence of these bands with those of graphene oxide confirms the successful synthesis of the magnetic graphene oxide composite. Upon functionalisation with ELE, the resulting ELE@MGO nanocomposite (Fig. 4b) largely retains the spectral features of MGO. However, it also exhibits additional peaks, which are ascribed to the various phytochemicals present in the plant extract. The FT-IR spectra for the final nanocomposites, Ni/ELE@MGO (Fig. 4c) and Cu/ELE@MGO (Fig. 4d), are markedly similar to that of their precursor, ELE@MGO. This spectral resemblance suggests that the incorporation of nickel and copper nanoparticles onto the surface did not fundamentally alter the underlying structure of the ELE@MGO support.

caption.p: FT-IR spectrum of MGO (a), ELE@MGO (b), Ni/ELE@MGO (c) and Cu/ELE@MGO (d).

sec.p: To determine the constituting elements in the final nanomaterial Ni/ELE@MGO and Cu/ELE@MGO, an EDX study was assessed (Fig. 5). Evidently, both the materials contain Fe, Cu as metallic and C, N and O as non-metallic elements. Fe and Cu are attributed to the MGO matrix whereas C, N and O are due to ELE phytochemicals over GO, thus supporting the anticipated structure. Additionally, Ni is found in the former material but Cu addendum separately could not be identified in the latter.

caption.p: EDX pattern of Ni/ELE@MGO (a) and Cu/ELE@MGO (b) nanocatalyst.

sec.p: The crystalline properties and phase composition of the Ni/ELE@MGO and Cu/ELE@MGO nanocomposites were investigated using X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, as depicted in Fig. 6. The XRD patterns of the catalysts reveal a single-phase profile, which suggests a well-integrated composite material where all components are cohesively bonded. The diffraction peaks corresponding to the (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), and (440) crystallographic planes are characteristic of the spinel structure of CuFe₂O₄ nanoparticles. The persistence of these diffraction peaks indicates that the fundamental crystal structure of the underlying magnetic nanoparticles is preserved throughout the sequential surface modification steps, including the incorporation of the eucalyptus leaf extract and the subsequent deposition of nickel or copper nanoparticles.

caption.p: XRD pattern of Ni/ELE@MGO (a) and Cu/ELE@MGO (b) nanocatalyst.

sec.p: The effective magnetism of the nanocatalyst can be examined using vibrating sample magnetometry (VSM) research. Both the Ni/ELE@MGO (a) and Cu/ELE@MGO (b) nanocatalysts exhibit superparamagnetic behavior, as demonstrated by the magnetometric analysis of their vibration sample (Fig. 7). Without any remanence or coercivity, they both depict a classic hysteresis curve. They were found to have respective saturation magnetization values (Ms) of 7.6 and 8.9 emu/g. Because the standard ferrites’ surfaces have been modified with ELE and GO, respectively, the values are quite low.

caption.p: Vibrating sample magnetometry cures of Ni/ELE@MGO (a) and Cu/ELE@MGO (b) nanocatalyst.

sec.p: The Ni/ELE@MGO (a) and Cu/ELE@MGO (b) (Fig. 8) catalysts were studied in greater detail using elemental mapping. The results from the EDX analysis were supplemented by elemental mapping research. It can be concluded that the improved catalytic activity is undoubtedly due to the homogenous structures of the active species because this study demonstrates that the elements Fe, Cu, Co, C, N, and O are uniformly distributed on the nanocomposite’s surface. The distribution of the elements shows that oxygen has a density that is much higher than nitrogen’s, indicating that phenolic species are the most prevalent in the phytochemicals found in the extract of eucalyptus leaves.

caption.p: (a) Elemental mapping of Ni/ELE@MGO nanocomposite. (b) Elemental mapping of Cu/ELE@MGO nanocomposite.

sec.p: Thermal analysis (TGA) is a useful technique for quantifying organic groups supported on the surface of a magnetic substrate in solid catalysts. The Ni/ELE@MGO (a) and Cu/ELE@MGO (b) matching curves are displayed in Fig. 9. The removal of solvents that have been physically and chemically absorbed or OH groups that have been bonded to the surface is linked to the mass decrease in the 50–200 °C range seen in the catalyst diagram. Both catalysts showed a notable breakdown between 200 and 600 °C, respectively, which was ascribed to the breakdown of plant organophytochemicals.

caption.p: The TGA diagrams of Ni/ELE@MGO (a) and Cu/ELE@MGO (b).

sec.p: The morphological characteristics of the synthesized catalytic system were investigated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM), with the resulting micrographs presented in Fig. 10. The images reveal the formation of nanoparticles exhibiting a nearly spherical morphology and a uniform size distribution. Significantly, these structural and morphological features were retained in the catalyst after its recovery from the reaction mixture. This observation provides evidence for the robust stability of the catalyst under the employed catalytic conditions. Therefore, the SEM analysis confirms that the engineered catalytic system possesses favorable morphological attributes and high structural integrity, which are desirable for its application.

caption.p: SEM analysis of Cu/ELE@MGO (a) and recovered Cu/ELE@MGO (b).

sec.title: Analysis of reaction data
sec.p: Following the successful synthesis of the Ni/ELE@MGO and Cu/ELE@MGO nanocatalysts, their catalytic efficacy was evaluated in the synthesis of tetrazole derivatives. To optimize the reaction conditions, Response Surface Methodology (RSM) was employed. Response Surface Methodology is a collection of statistical and mathematical techniques used for developing, improving, and optimizing processes. In this approach, a set of designed experiments is conducted to investigate the relationship between several process variables and one or more response variables. The primary objective of RSM is to build an experimental model of the process and subsequently use this model to identify the optimal conditions that yield a maximum or minimum response. This methodology is widely utilized in academia and industry to achieve consistent and optimized outcomes in various applications, including chemical synthesis.

To optimize the synthesis of tetrazole derivatives, Response Surface Methodology (RSM) was utilized. RSM is widely applied to experimental and numerical models to determine optimal process conditions. A critical component of this methodology is the choice of an appropriate experimental design, which directly influences the predictive accuracy of the resulting model. For this investigation, a Box-Behnken Design (BBD) was selected. The BBD is a three-level, incomplete factorial design that is particularly advantageous for studies involving up to four variables, as it requires a smaller number of experimental runs compared to other designs. This efficiency addresses the challenge of managing a large number of experiments when multiple variables are being investigated. The design involves performing sets of two-level factorial experiments at different combinations of the variable levels.

In this study, the BBD was employed to create a precise and reliable experimental framework. Three key process parameters were varied: catalyst amount (mg), reaction time (h), and temperature (°C). A total of 17 experiments were conducted with randomized parameter combinations to determine the optimal conditions for the synthesis of tetrazole derivatives, as detailed in Table 1. Analysis of the experimental data revealed that the quantity of the catalyst was the most influential factor in maximizing the reaction yield. The optimal conditions were found to be a catalyst loading of 20 mg, a temperature of 120 °C, and a reaction time of 120 min. Under these conditions, a maximum yield of 98% for the tetrazole derivative was achieved using both the Ni/ELE@MGO and Cu/ELE@MGO nanocatalysts.

caption.p: Experimental data for the optimized yield of synthesis of 5-(4-nitrophenyl)-1H-tetrazole in various conditions over ni/ele@mgo (a) and cu/ele@mgo (b)nanocatalysts.

sec.p: The RSM predicted parameters had a stronger correlation with the interaction coefficients, ANOVA’s linear and quadratic effects. Variable parameters and probability values of correlation coefficients for both the two nanocatalysts Ni/ELE@MGO (Table 2) and Cu/ELE@MGO (Table 3) have been investigated. In both the catalysts, P values for the model were obtained as ≤ 0.0001. For adjustment, fit, and goodness of prediction, the Ni/ELE@MGO catalyst’s regression coefficients (R2) were 0.7174, 0.8168, and 0.8511, respectively. For the Cu/ELE@MGO catalyst, the corresponding values were 0.6549, 0.7954, and 0.8337. As demonstrated by the R2 score, which is near unity (1.0), our constructed model is close to the standard. Additionally, three models’ accuracy values were found to be 16.7493 and 15.8437, respectively, which are regarded as excellent (< 4.0).

caption.p: Analysis of variance (ANOVA) for the synthesis of 5-(4-nitrophenyl)-1 H-tetrazole in the presence ofni/ele@mgo.
Analysis of variance (ANOVA) for the 5-(4-nitrophenyl)-1H-tetrazole in the presence of Cu/ELE@MGO.

sec.p: The developed regression model was validated using ANOVA by plotting the experimental or real values of the parameters against the projected values. Both the Ni/ELE@MGO (a) and Cu/ELE@MGO (b) catalysts’ parameter values astonishingly closely match those in Fig. 11. This shows that the regression model can account for the relationship between the response, tetrazole formation performance, and the independent factors. Since all of the data are centered on an average straight line, the likelihood of inaccuracy is extremely low.

caption.p: The evaluation of predicted value against the actual value by the RSM in Ni/ELE@MGO (a) and Cu/ELE@MGO (b)nanocatalysts.

sec.p: RSM was also used to create 3D response surface contour plots that demonstrate how independent variables or parameters affect dependent variables, specifically the tetrazole yield. The contour plot in Fig. 12a,b shows how changes in catalyst amount, temperature, and time affect the tetrazole yield (%) for Ni/ELE@MGO, and the contour plot in Fig. 12c,d shows the same for Cu/ELE@MGO. In Fig. 12a,c, productivity increases as the Cu/ELE@MGO and Ni/ELE@MGO catalysts load increases from 10 mg to 30 mg and also when the temperature is raised from 80°C to 120°C. Once more, the efficiency (%) varies with different reaction times for Cu/ELE@MGO and Ni/ELE@MGO catalysts.

caption.p: 3D response surface plots of A: amount of catalyst, B: temperature and C: Time for Ni/ELE@MGO (a and b) and Cu/ELE@MGO (c and d) nanocatalysts.

sec.p: Under the optimal conditions identified by the response surface approach software, the various tetrazole derivatives were investigated in the presence of these catalysts (Table 4).

table-wrap-foot.p: aIsolated yields, reaction continued for 2 h.

sec.p: Additionally, a rational mechanistic pathway for the aforementioned synthesis has been devised and is shown in Fig. 1361. To make the N atom of azide more nucleophilic, the metal nanocatalyst active site pulls the π electron density on the nitrile group by chelating. The process of [3 + 2] cycloaddition is subsequently coordinated to produce the tetrazole. The 5-aryl-1 H-tetrazole moiety is liberated by protonation and further catalyst-assisted molecular rearrangement. The catalytic site then becomes free and ready for further cycle.

caption.p: Possible reaction mechanism for the synthesis oftetrazole derivatives in the presence of catalyst.

sec.title: Reusability of catalyst
sec.p: A crucial characteristic of any heterogeneous catalyst is its ability to be easily and economically separated from the reaction mixture and subsequently reused over multiple reaction cycles without a significant loss of catalytic activity. This aspect is of particular importance in industrial applications, where cost-effectiveness and process sustainability are paramount. In this context, magnetic catalysts have garnered considerable attention as they offer a straightforward and efficient method for catalyst separation through the application of an external magnetic field. To this end, the recovery and recyclability of the synthesized Cu/ELE@MGO and Ni/ELE@MGO catalysts were investigated in the synthesis of 5-(4-nitrophenyl)-1 H-tetrazole under the previously optimized reaction conditions. As illustrated in Fig. 14, both catalytic systems demonstrated exceptional stability and performance over a number of consecutive cycles in the production of 5-(4-nitrophenyl)-1 H-tetrazole.

caption.p: Reusability of Cu/ELE@MGO (a) and Ni/ELE@MGO (b) catalysts forthe synthesis of 5-(4-nitrophenyl)-1H-tetrazole.

sec.title: Hot filtration and leaching test
sec.p: A hot filtration test was conducted to ascertain the stability of the Cu/ELE@MGO catalyst and to verify its heterogeneous nature during the synthesis of 5-(4-nitrophenyl)-1 H-tetrazole. The reaction was allowed to proceed to approximately its midpoint, at which a yield of 46% was recorded. The solid catalyst was then removed from the hot reaction mixture via filtration, and the filtrate was allowed to continue reacting under the same conditions. Upon completion, the final yield of the filtrate reaction was 48%. The marginal increase in yield (2%) after the removal of the catalyst indicates that the reaction did not significantly progress in the absence of the solid material. This result strongly suggests that there was negligible leaching of active copper species from the support into the solution, thereby confirming the truly heterogeneous nature of the Cu/ELE@MGO catalytic system.

sec.title: Comparison of catalyst
sec.p: The catalyst produced in this study was evaluated for activity against those found in earlier reports. Benefits of the proposed approach include the use of copper and nickel as green and accessible metals, the use of eucalyptus leaf extract as a green ligand, the use of polyethylene glycol as a green solvent, facile catalyst separation, and chemical and thermal stability. The catalyst has a quick reaction time and a high efficiency. Also, in the synthesis of tetrazole derivatives, RSM method was used for optimization, which increases accuracy and reduces costs by simultaneously analyzing multiple factors. Table 5 displays the related outcomes.

caption.p: Uniqueness of catalytic results of cu/ele@mgo in the synthesis of 5-(4-methoxyphenyl-1H-tetrazole.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study reports the successful green synthesis of novel Ni/ELE@MGO and Cu/ELE@MGO nanocatalysts. These materials were prepared by immobilizing nickel and copper nanoparticles, derived from Eucalyptus leaf extract (ELE), onto a magnetic graphene oxide (MGO) support. The successful formation and structural properties of these nanocatalysts were rigorously confirmed through various physicochemical characterization techniques. The catalytic performance of the synthesized Ni/ELE@MGO and Cu/ELE@MGO nanoparticles was subsequently evaluated in the synthesis of tetrazole derivatives, a class of compounds with extensive applications in fields such as energetic materials, pharmaceuticals, biochemistry, and bioimaging. To maximize the reaction efficiency, Response Surface Methodology (RSM) was employed to systematically optimize the key reaction parameters, leading to the identification of conditions for achieving high product yields. A significant advantage of the developed catalytic system is the use of earth-abundant and inexpensive metals, nickel and copper, as effective substitutes for costly noble metals like palladium, which are often used in similar transformations. The combination of strong catalytic performance, demonstrated reusability over multiple cycles, and facile magnetic separation renders this methodology an economically viable and environmentally benign approach for the synthesis of valuable tetrazole compounds.
